content: Airline passenger screening in the United States has evolved significantly since the 9/11 attacks, with new technologies like advanced X-ray systems and whole-body scanners, along with policy changes such as requiring laptop removal and liquid screening. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) oversees these changes, mandated by the Aviation Transportation and Security Act (ATSA) to ensure comprehensive security screening for all passengers and property on airline flights. Trusted traveler programs and expedited security measures are also implemented by TSA. The Aviation Transportation and Security Act (ATSA) mandated TSA to provide comprehensive security screening for all airline passengers and property. Congress also directed TSA to check all passengers against terrorist watchlists. Despite challenges in implementing risk-based screening, TSA has mostly relied on a uniform risk assumption for airport checkpoint screening. The TSA has faced challenges in passenger screening, leading to a reliance on a uniform risk assumption for airport checkpoint screening.
